topic: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question:
Investors in commercial mortgage-backed securities (CMBS) face balloon risk, which is most likely a type of:

  1. call risk.
  2. extension risk.
  3. contraction risk.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because balloon risk is the risk that the borrower will not be able to arrange for refinancing or sell the property to make the balloon payment typically associated with commercial loans backing CMBS. As a result, the CMBS may extend in maturity, implying that balloon risk is a type of extension (not call) risk. Correct. Balloon risk is the risk that the borrower will not be able to arrange for refinancing or sell the property to make the balloon payment typically associated with commercial loans backing CMBS. As a result, the CMBS may extend in maturity, implying that balloon risk is a type of extension risk. Incorrect because balloon risk is the risk that the borrower will not be able to arrange for refinancing or sell the property to make the balloon payment typically associated with commercial loans backing CMBS. As a result, the CMBS may extend in maturity, implying that balloon risk is a type of extension (not contraction) risk. Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features describe characteristics and risks of commercial mortgage-backed securities
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because balloon risk is the risk that the borrower will not be able to arrange for refinancing or sell the property to make the balloon payment typically associated with commercial loans backing CMBS. As a result, the CMBS may extend in maturity, implying that balloon risk is a type of extension (not call) risk.

  2. Correct. Balloon risk is the risk that the borrower will not be able to arrange for refinancing or sell the property to make the balloon payment typically associated with commercial loans backing CMBS. As a result, the CMBS may extend in maturity, implying that balloon risk is a type of extension risk.

  3. Incorrect because balloon risk is the risk that the borrower will not be able to arrange for refinancing or sell the property to make the balloon payment typically associated with commercial loans backing CMBS. As a result, the CMBS may extend in maturity, implying that balloon risk is a type of extension (not contraction) risk.

Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features

  • describe characteristics and risks of commercial mortgage-backed securities

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question: Compare the credit rating of the Class A bonds issued by the SPE and the uncollateralized bonds issued directly by AR&C. The Class A bonds are most likely rated:
questions.explanation: Solution The correct answer is C. The Class A bonds issued by the SPE are backed by collateral, the leases sold by AR&C to the SPE, and they are the most senior of the bonds issued by the SPE. A secured bond is secured by collateral and is considered less risky than a bond without collateral backing. The Class A bonds issued by the SPE would most likely be rated higher than any unsecured corporate bonds issued directly by AR&C.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

The correct answer is C. The Class A bonds issued by the SPE are backed by collateral, the leases sold by AR&C to the SPE, and they are the most senior of the bonds issued by the SPE. A secured bond is secured by collateral and is considered less risky than a bond without collateral backing. The Class A bonds issued by the SPE would most likely be rated higher than any unsecured corporate bonds issued directly by AR&C.

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question:
Which of the following is least likely a feature typical of an agency residential mortgage-backed security (RMBS)?

  1. A guarantee by a government-sponsored enterprise
  2. The use of credit enhancements to reduce credit risk
  3. The satisfaction of specific established underwriting standards
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because agency RMBS include securities issued by government agencies. These RMBS carry the full faith and credit of the government, essentially a guarantee with respect to timely payment of interest and repayment of principal. Agency RMBS also include RMBS issued by GSEs. Correct because RMBS issued by GSEs do not carry the full faith and credit of the government, but rather the GSEsâ€™ guarantee of the timely payment of interest and principal for the securities. The GSEâ€™s charge a fee for this guarantee. Due to changing regulatory guidance and increased scrutiny, non-agency-RMBS all but disappeared after the global financial crisis. They were issued by banks, financial institutions, and other private businesses and were not beneficiaries of government guarantees. These private pass-throughs or private label MBS gained credit enhancement through pool insurance, letters of credit, guarantees, or subordination. Incorrect because non-agency RMBS securitized mortgages were collateralized by non-conforming mortgages, or by subprime, highly risky mortgages. Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features describe fundamental features of residential mortgage loans that are securitized
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because agency RMBS include securities issued by government agencies. These RMBS carry the full faith and credit of the government, essentially a guarantee with respect to timely payment of interest and repayment of principal. Agency RMBS also include RMBS issued by GSEs.

  2. Correct because RMBS issued by GSEs do not carry the full faith and credit of the government, but rather the GSEsâ€™ guarantee of the timely payment of interest and principal for the securities. The GSEâ€™s charge a fee for this guarantee. Due to changing regulatory guidance and increased scrutiny, non-agency-RMBS all but disappeared after the global financial crisis. They were issued by banks, financial institutions, and other private businesses and were not beneficiaries of government guarantees. These private pass-throughs or private label MBS gained credit enhancement through pool insurance, letters of credit, guarantees, or subordination.

  3. Incorrect because non-agency RMBS securitized mortgages were collateralized by non-conforming mortgages, or by subprime, highly risky mortgages.

Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features

  • describe fundamental features of residential mortgage loans that are securitized

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question: Select which of the following statements related to the collateralized bonds issued directly by the SPE is most accurate.

choices.A: This senior/subordinated structure is an example of time tranching.
choices.B: Losses are realized by the subordinated bond classes before any losses are realized by Class A bonds.
choices.C: In a waterfall structure such as this one, losses are shared proportionally across all subordinated bond classes.

questions.explanation: Solution The correct answer is B. Losses are realized by the subordinated bond classes before any losses are realized by the senior Class A bonds. A is incorrect because this senior/subordinated structure is an example of credit tranching, not time tranching. C is incorrect because in a waterfall structure such as this one, the most junior tranche, Class D, will absorb all losses up to its full CAD50 million par value first. Then, if credit losses exceed that threshold, Bond Class C will absorb all losses up to its full CAD100 million par value. The losses are not shared proportionally across all subordinated bond classes; instead, they are absorbed by the most junior classes first and subsequently by the more senior ones up to the value of the loss.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

The correct answer is B. Losses are realized by the subordinated bond classes before any losses are realized by the senior Class A bonds. A is incorrect because this senior/subordinated structure is an example of credit tranching, not time tranching. C is incorrect because in a waterfall structure such as this one, the most junior tranche, Class D, will absorb all losses up to its full CAD50 million par value first. Then, if credit losses exceed that threshold, Bond Class C will absorb all losses up to its full CAD100 million par value. The losses are not shared proportionally across all subordinated bond classes; instead, they are absorbed by the most junior classes first and subsequently by the more senior ones up to the value of the loss.

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question:
In a mortgage pass-through security, the pass-through rate:

  1. is adjusted as market rates rise or fall.
  2. is equal to the mortgage rate on the underlying pool of mortgages.
  3. adjusts the rate on the underlying pool of mortgages by a servicing fee.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because in a mortgage pass-through security, the pass-through rate is less than the mortgage rate on the underlying pool of mortgages by an amount equal to the servicing (and other administrative) fees. Incorrect because in a mortgage pass-through security, the pass-through rate is less than the mortgage rate on the underlying pool of mortgages by an amount equal to the servicing (and other administrative) fees. Correct. In a mortgage pass-through security, the pass-through rate is less than the mortgage rate on the underlying pool of mortgages by an amount equal to the servicing (and other administrative) fees. Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features describe types and characteristics of residential mortgage-backed securities, including mortgage pass-through securities and collateralized mortgage obligations, and explain the cash flows and risks for each type
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because in a mortgage pass-through security, the pass-through rate is less than the mortgage rate on the underlying pool of mortgages by an amount equal to the servicing (and other administrative) fees.

  2. Incorrect because in a mortgage pass-through security, the pass-through rate is less than the mortgage rate on the underlying pool of mortgages by an amount equal to the servicing (and other administrative) fees.

  3. Correct. In a mortgage pass-through security, the pass-through rate is less than the mortgage rate on the underlying pool of mortgages by an amount equal to the servicing (and other administrative) fees.

Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features

  • describe types and characteristics of residential mortgage-backed securities, including mortgage pass-through securities and collateralized mortgage obligations, and explain the cash flows and risks for each type

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question:
An investor who owns a mortgage pass-through security is exposed to contraction risk, which is the risk that when interest rates:

  1. rise, the security will effectively have a shorter maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase.
  2. decline, the security will effectively have a longer maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase.
  3. decline, the security will effectively have a shorter maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because contraction risk is the risk faced by investors when interest rates fall, not rise, in that the security will effectively have a shorter maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase because homeowners can refinance at new, lower interest rates. Incorrect because contraction risk is the risk faced by investors when interest rates fall in that the security will effectively have a shorter, not longer, maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase because homeowners can refinance at new, lower interest rates. Correct. Contraction risk is the risk faced by investors when interest rates fall in that the security will effectively have a shorter maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase because homeowners can refinance at new, lower interest rates. Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features define prepayment risk and describe time tranching structures in securitizations and their purpose
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because contraction risk is the risk faced by investors when interest rates fall, not rise, in that the security will effectively have a shorter maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase because homeowners can refinance at new, lower interest rates.

  2. Incorrect because contraction risk is the risk faced by investors when interest rates fall in that the security will effectively have a shorter, not longer, maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase because homeowners can refinance at new, lower interest rates.

  3. Correct. Contraction risk is the risk faced by investors when interest rates fall in that the security will effectively have a shorter maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase because homeowners can refinance at new, lower interest rates.

Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features

  • define prepayment risk and describe time tranching structures in securitizations and their purpose

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question:
An investor who owns a mortgage pass-through security is exposed to extension risk, which is the risk that when interest rates:

  1. fall, the security will effectively have a shorter maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase.
  2. rise, the security will effectively have a shorter maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase.
  3. rise, the security will effectively have a longer maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because extension risk is the risk faced that when interest rates rise (not fall), fewer prepayments will occur because homeowners are reluctant to give up the benefits of a contractual interest rate that is now lower than the market rate. As a result, the security becomes longer in maturity than anticipated at the time of purchase. Incorrect because extension risk is the risk faced that when interest rates rise, fewer prepayments will occur because homeowners are reluctant to give up the benefits of a contractual interest rate that is now lower than the market rate. As a result, the security becomes longer (not shorter) in maturity than anticipated at the time of purchase. Correct. Extension risk is the risk faced that when interest rates rise, fewer prepayments will occur because homeowners will be reluctant to give up the benefits of a contractual interest rate that is now lower than the market rate. As a result, the security becomes longer in maturity than anticipated at the time of purchase. Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features define prepayment risk and describe time tranching structures in securitizations and their purpose
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because extension risk is the risk faced that when interest rates rise (not fall), fewer prepayments will occur because homeowners are reluctant to give up the benefits of a contractual interest rate that is now lower than the market rate. As a result, the security becomes longer in maturity than anticipated at the time of purchase.

  2. Incorrect because extension risk is the risk faced that when interest rates rise, fewer prepayments will occur because homeowners are reluctant to give up the benefits of a contractual interest rate that is now lower than the market rate. As a result, the security becomes longer (not shorter) in maturity than anticipated at the time of purchase.

  3. Correct. Extension risk is the risk faced that when interest rates rise, fewer prepayments will occur because homeowners will be reluctant to give up the benefits of a contractual interest rate that is now lower than the market rate. As a result, the security becomes longer in maturity than anticipated at the time of purchase.

Mortgage-Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features

  • define prepayment risk and describe time tranching structures in securitizations and their purpose

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question: For a CMO that includes Planned Amortization Class (PAC) tranches, if the prepayment rate is within the anticipated range, which of the following tranches most likely protects investors from prepayment risk?
questions.explanation: Solution The correct answer is C. If the prepayment rate is within the specified range, all prepayment risk is absorbed by the support tranche. This provides greater predictability of the size and timing of cash flows paid to investors in the PAC tranches. A is incorrect because in a CMO that includes a PAC tranche, the PAC tranche is protected from prepayment risk because all prepayment risk is absorbed by the support tranche. B is incorrect because in a CMO that includes a PAC tranche, the senior (PAC) tranche is protected from prepayment risk because all prepayment risk is absorbed by the support tranche.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

The correct answer is C. If the prepayment rate is within the specified range, all prepayment risk is absorbed by the support tranche. This provides greater predictability of the size and timing of cash flows paid to investors in the PAC tranches.

A is incorrect because in a CMO that includes a PAC tranche, the PAC tranche is protected from prepayment risk because all prepayment risk is absorbed by the support tranche.

B is incorrect because in a CMO that includes a PAC tranche, the senior (PAC) tranche is protected from prepayment risk because all prepayment risk is absorbed by the support tranche.

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question: Which of the following approaches redistributes prepayment risk?
questions.explanation: Solution The correct answer is A. The tranching structure in CMOs cannot eliminate prepayment risk, but it can redistribute prepayment risk across the different tranches, insulating some tranches more than others. CMO tranche structures reduce the uncertainties of the size and timing of payments investors receive. B and C are incorrect because excess spread and overcollateralization are both common forms of credit enhancement, but they do not redistribute prepayment risk.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

The correct answer is A. The tranching structure in CMOs cannot eliminate prepayment risk, but it can redistribute prepayment risk across the different tranches, insulating some tranches more than others. CMO tranche structures reduce the uncertainties of the size and timing of payments investors receive.

B and C are incorrect because excess spread and overcollateralization are both common forms of credit enhancement, but they do not redistribute prepayment risk.

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question:
Shown below are five mortgages that comprise the entire pool in a mortgage-backed security.

Mortgage Interest Rate
(i) 		Beginning Balance
(BB) 		Current Balance
(CB) 		Original Term (months) Number of Months to Maturity
A 2.00% CAD200,000 CAD83,000 420 140
B 3.00% CAD300,000 CAD193,000 360 192
C 4.00% CAD400,000 CAD315,000 360 240
D 5.00% CAD500,000 CAD357,000 240 144
E 6.00% CAD600,000 CAD548,000 420 324
CAD2,000,000 CAD1,496,000

The WAM for this security is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution The correct answer is C. The weighted average maturity is calculated by weighting the number of months to maturity for each mortgage in the pool by the percentage of the outstanding mortgage balance relative to the outstanding amount of all the mortgages in the pool, as shown in the following equation: ğ‘Š ğ´ ğ‘€ = ğ‘€ ğ‘€ ğ´ ( ğ¶ ğµ ğ´ âˆ‘ ğ¶ ğµ ) + ğ‘€ ğ‘€ ğµ ( ğ¶ ğµ ğµ âˆ‘ ğ¶ ğµ ) + ğ‘€ ğ‘€ ğ¶ ( ğ¶ ğµ ğ¶ âˆ‘ ğ¶ ğµ ) + ğ‘€ ğ‘€ ğ· ( ğ¶ ğµ ğ· âˆ‘ ğ¶ ğµ ) + ğ‘€ ğ‘€ ğ¸ ( ğ¶ ğµ ğ¸ âˆ‘ ğ¶ ğµ ) W A M = M M A C B A âˆ‘ C B + M M B C B B âˆ‘ C B + M M C C B C âˆ‘ C B + M M D C B D âˆ‘ C B + M M E C B E âˆ‘ C B ğ‘Š ğ´ ğ‘€ = 140 ( 83 , 000 1 , 496 , 000 ) + 192 ( 193 , 000 1 , 496 , 000 ) + 240 ( 315 , 000 1 , 496 , 000 ) + 144 ( 357 , 000 1 , 496 , 000 ) + 324 ( 548 , 000 1 , 496 , 000 ) W A M = 140 83 , 000 1 , 496 , 000 + 192 193 , 000 1 , 496 , 000 + 240 315 , 000 1 , 496 , 000 + 144 357 , 000 1 , 496 , 000 + 324 548 , 000 1 , 496 , 000 WAM = 236 months. A is incorrect because it is calculated by averaging the months to maturity for the five mortgages, rather than calculating their weighted average. B is incorrect because it is calculated by weighting the number of months to maturity for each mortgage in the pool by the percentage of the beginning mortgage balance relative to the beginning amount of all the mortgages in the pool, not by the current balances.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

The correct answer is C. The weighted average maturity is calculated by weighting the number of months to maturity for each mortgage in the pool by the percentage of the outstanding mortgage balance relative to the outstanding amount of all the mortgages in the pool, as shown in the following equation:

ğ‘Šğ´ğ‘€=ğ‘€ğ‘€ğ´(ğ¶ğµğ´âˆ‘ğ¶ğµ)+ğ‘€ğ‘€ğµ(ğ¶ğµğµâˆ‘ğ¶ğµ)+ğ‘€ğ‘€ğ¶(ğ¶ğµğ¶âˆ‘ğ¶ğµ)+ğ‘€ğ‘€ğ·(ğ¶ğµğ·âˆ‘ğ¶ğµ)+ğ‘€ğ‘€ğ¸(ğ¶ğµğ¸âˆ‘ğ¶ğµ)WAM=MMACBAâˆ‘CB+MMBCBBâˆ‘CB+MMCCBCâˆ‘CB+MMDCBDâˆ‘CB+MMECBEâˆ‘CBğ‘Šğ´ğ‘€=140(83,0001,496,000)+192(193,0001,496,000)+240(315,0001,496,000)+144(357,0001,496,000)+324(548,0001,496,000)WAM=14083,0001,496,000+192193,0001,496,000+240315,0001,496,000+144357,0001,496,000+324548,0001,496,000WAM = 236 months.

A is incorrect because it is calculated by averaging the months to maturity for the five mortgages, rather than calculating their weighted average.

B is incorrect because it is calculated by weighting the number of months to maturity for each mortgage in the pool by the percentage of the beginning mortgage balance relative to the beginning amount of all the mortgages in the pool, not by the current balances.

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question: Which of the following adverse consequences is most likely associated with extension risk?

choices.A: Investors must reinvest the proceeds at lower interest rates.
choices.B: Higher interest rates reduce the value of the cash flows investors receive.
choices.C: The prepayment option reduces the potential price appreciation for the bond.

questions.explanation: Solution The correct answer is B. Extension risk is the risk that the borrower might pay back the money borrowed more slowly than anticipated, extending the time of repayment and the maturity of the bond. For investors, this has one adverse consequence: Higher interest rates reduce the value of the cash flows investors receive. The payments the investors receive will be discounted at a higher interest rate, and the extension stretches out the payments the investors receive. A is incorrect because contraction risk (the risk that the borrower might pay back the money borrowed more quickly than anticipated, reducing the amount of future payments the investor receives), not extension risk, has the adverse consequence that investors must reinvest the proceeds at lower interest rates. C is incorrect because contraction risk (the risk that the borrower might pay back the money borrowed more quickly than anticipated, reducing the amount of future payments the investor receives), not extension risk, has the adverse consequence that the prepayment option reduces the potential price appreciation for the bond.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

The correct answer is B. Extension risk is the risk that the borrower might pay back the money borrowed more slowly than anticipated, extending the time of repayment and the maturity of the bond. For investors, this has one adverse consequence: Higher interest rates reduce the value of the cash flows investors receive. The payments the investors receive will be discounted at a higher interest rate, and the extension stretches out the payments the investors receive.

A is incorrect because contraction risk (the risk that the borrower might pay back the money borrowed more quickly than anticipated, reducing the amount of future payments the investor receives), not extension risk, has the adverse consequence that investors must reinvest the proceeds at lower interest rates.

C is incorrect because contraction risk (the risk that the borrower might pay back the money borrowed more quickly than anticipated, reducing the amount of future payments the investor receives), not extension risk, has the adverse consequence that the prepayment option reduces the potential price appreciation for the bond.

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question: The associated loan to value ratio is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution The correct answer is A. The associated loan to value ratio is calculated as the total value of all loans (mortgages) divided by the total value of the properties associated with the mortgages, as follows: ğ¿ ğ‘‡ ğ‘‰ = ğ‘‡ ğ‘œ ğ‘¡ ğ‘ ğ‘™ ğ‘£ ğ‘ ğ‘™ ğ‘¢ ğ‘’ ğ‘œ ğ‘“ ğ‘ ğ‘™ ğ‘™ ğ‘™ ğ‘œ ğ‘ ğ‘› ğ‘  ( ğ‘š ğ‘œ ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘¡ ğ‘” ğ‘ ğ‘” ğ‘’ ğ‘  ) ğ‘‡ ğ‘œ ğ‘¡ ğ‘ ğ‘™ ğ‘£ ğ‘ ğ‘™ ğ‘¢ ğ‘’ ğ‘œ ğ‘“ ğ‘ ğ‘™ ğ‘™ ğ‘ ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘œ ğ‘ ğ‘’ ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘¡ ğ‘– ğ‘’ ğ‘  ğ‘š ğ‘œ ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘¡ ğ‘” ğ‘ ğ‘” ğ‘’ ğ‘‘ L T V = T o t a l v a l u e o f a l l l o a n s m o r t g a g e s T o t a l v a l u e o f a l l p r o p e r t i e s m o r t g a g e d ğ¿ ğ‘‡ ğ‘‰ = 83 , 000 , 000 110 , 000 , 000 = 0.75 L T V = 83 , 000 , 000 110 , 000 , 000 = 0.75 . B is incorrect because 0.77 is the value of just the mortgage on the first property (27,000,000) divided by the first propertyâ€™s total value (35,000,000). C is incorrect because 0.80 is the value of just the mortgage on the third property (11,400,000) divided by the third propertyâ€™s total value (15,000,000).
questions.solution_html:
Solution

The correct answer is A. The associated loan to value ratio is calculated as the total value of all loans (mortgages) divided by the total value of the properties associated with the mortgages, as follows:

B is incorrect because 0.77 is the value of just the mortgage on the first property (27,000,000) divided by the first propertyâ€™s total value (35,000,000).

C is incorrect because 0.80 is the value of just the mortgage on the third property (11,400,000) divided by the third propertyâ€™s total value (15,000,000).

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question: The weighted average coupon payment is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution The correct answer is A. The weighted average coupon payment is calculated as the value of each trancheâ€™s coupon rate weighted by the principal value of that tranche as a percentage of the total value of all tranches: ğ‘Š ğ´ ğ¶ = ğ‘– ğ´ ( ğ¶ ğµ ğ´ âˆ‘ ğ¶ ğµ ) + ğ‘– ğµ ( ğ¶ ğµ ğµ âˆ‘ ğ¶ ğµ ) + ğ‘– ğ¶ ( ğ¶ ğµ ğ¶ âˆ‘ ğ¶ ğµ ) + ğ‘– ğ· ( ğ¶ ğµ ğ· âˆ‘ ğ¶ ğµ ) W A C = i A C B A âˆ‘ C B + i B C B B âˆ‘ C B + i C C B C âˆ‘ C B + i D C B D âˆ‘ C B ğ‘Š ğ´ ğ¶ = 2.00 % ( 20 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 ) + 3.00 % ( 22 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 ) + 4.00 % ( 23 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 ) + 5.00 % ( 18 , 000 , 000 23 , 000 , 000 ) W A C = 2.00 % 20 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 + 3.00 % 22 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 + 4.00 % 23 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 + 5.00 % 18 , 000 , 000 23 , 000 , 000 ğ‘Š ğ´ ğ¶ = 3.47 % W A C = 3.47 % . B is incorrect because 3.50% is calculated as a straight average of the four coupon rates (of the four tranches), rather than a weighted average. C is incorrect because 3.61% is the weighted proceeds from the three mortgages, not the weighted average coupon payment.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

The correct answer is A. The weighted average coupon payment is calculated as the value of each trancheâ€™s coupon rate weighted by the principal value of that tranche as a percentage of the total value of all tranches:

ğ‘Šğ´ğ¶=ğ‘–ğ´(ğ¶ğµğ´âˆ‘ğ¶ğµ)+ğ‘–ğµ(ğ¶ğµğµâˆ‘ğ¶ğµ)+ğ‘–ğ¶(ğ¶ğµğ¶âˆ‘ğ¶ğµ)+ğ‘–ğ·(ğ¶ğµğ·âˆ‘ğ¶ğµ)WAC=iACBAâˆ‘CB+iBCBBâˆ‘CB+iCCBCâˆ‘CB+iDCBDâˆ‘CBğ‘Šğ´ğ¶=2.00%(20,000,00083,000,000)+3.00%(22,000,00083,000,000)+4.00%(23,000,00083,000,000)+5.00%(18,000,00023,000,000)WAC=2.00%20,000,00083,000,000+3.00%22,000,00083,000,000+4.00%23,000,00083,000,000+5.00%18,000,00023,000,000ğ‘Šğ´ğ¶=3.47%WAC=3.47%.

B is incorrect because 3.50% is calculated as a straight average of the four coupon rates (of the four tranches), rather than a weighted average.

C is incorrect because 3.61% is the weighted proceeds from the three mortgages, not the weighted average coupon payment.

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question: The weighted average proceeds from the mortgages is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution The correct answer is C. The weighted average proceeds from the mortgages ( WAMP shown below) is calculated as the coupon rate of each mortgage weighted by that mortgageâ€™s value/amount as a percentage of the total value of all the mortgages: ğ‘Š ğ´ ğ‘€ ğ‘ƒ = ğ‘– ğ´ ( ğ‘€ ğ´ ğ´ âˆ‘ ğ‘€ ğ´ ) + ğ‘– ğµ ( ğ‘€ ğ´ ğµ âˆ‘ ğ‘€ ğ´ ) + ğ‘– ğ¶ ( ğ‘€ ğ´ ğ¶ âˆ‘ ğ‘€ ğ´ ) W A M P = i A M A A âˆ‘ M A + i B M A B âˆ‘ M A + i C M A C âˆ‘ M A ğ‘Š ğ´ ğ‘€ ğ‘ƒ = 4.00 % ( 27 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 ) + 3.00 % ( 44 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 ) + 5.00 % ( 12 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 ) W A M P = 4.00 % 27 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 + 3.00 % 44 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 + 5.00 % 12 , 000 , 000 83 , 000 , 000 ğ‘Š ğ´ ğ‘€ ğ‘ƒ = 3.61 % W A M P = 3.61 % . A is incorrect because 3.47% is the weighted average coupon payment for the four tranches, not the weighted average proceeds from the mortgages. B is incorrect because 3.50% is calculated as a straight average of the four coupon rates (of the four tranches), not the weighted average proceeds from the mortgages.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

The correct answer is C. The weighted average proceeds from the mortgages (WAMP shown below) is calculated as the coupon rate of each mortgage weighted by that mortgageâ€™s value/amount as a percentage of the total value of all the mortgages:

ğ‘Šğ´ğ‘€ğ‘ƒ=ğ‘–ğ´(ğ‘€ğ´ğ´âˆ‘ğ‘€ğ´)+ğ‘–ğµ(ğ‘€ğ´ğµâˆ‘ğ‘€ğ´)+ğ‘–ğ¶(ğ‘€ğ´ğ¶âˆ‘ğ‘€ğ´)WAMP=iAMAAâˆ‘MA+iBMABâˆ‘MA+iCMACâˆ‘MAğ‘Šğ´ğ‘€ğ‘ƒ=4.00%(27,000,00083,000,000)+3.00%(44,000,00083,000,000)+5.00%(12,000,00083,000,000)WAMP=4.00%27,000,00083,000,000+3.00%44,000,00083,000,000+5.00%12,000,00083,000,000

ğ‘Šğ´ğ‘€ğ‘ƒ=3.61%WAMP=3.61%.

A is incorrect because 3.47% is the weighted average coupon payment for the four tranches, not the weighted average proceeds from the mortgages.

B is incorrect because 3.50% is calculated as a straight average of the four coupon rates (of the four tranches), not the weighted average proceeds from the mortgages.

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question: Which of the following would most likely increase balloon risk for a commercial mortgage loan that is maturing?

choices.C: Lack of property buyers in market

questions.explanation: Solution The correct answer is C. A lack of property buyers in the market will make it challenging for a borrower to sell a property to generate sufficient funds to pay off the outstanding principal balance. A is incorrect because a high DSCR would reduce the balloon risk. B is incorrect because a low LTV ratio would also reduce the balloon risk of a maturing loan.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

The correct answer is C. A lack of property buyers in the market will make it challenging for a borrower to sell a property to generate sufficient funds to pay off the outstanding principal balance. A is incorrect because a high DSCR would reduce the balloon risk. B is incorrect because a low LTV ratio would also reduce the balloon risk of a maturing loan.

questions.title: Mortgage Backed Security (MBS) Instrument and Market Features
questions.question: Which of the following provides call protection for CMBS investors at the structural level?
questions.explanation: Solution The correct answer is C. Structural call protection is achieved through sequential-pay tranches in the CMBS as a lower-rated tranche cannot be paid down until the higher-rated tranche is completely retired. A is incorrect because defeasance provides call protection at the individual loan level. Defeasance allows prepayment, but the borrower must purchase a portfolio of government securities that fully replicates the cash flows of the remaining scheduled principal and interest payments, including the balloon loan balance, on the loan. B is incorrect because prepayment lockout provides call protection at the individual loan level. Prepayment lockout is a contractual agreement that prohibits any prepayments during a specified period.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

The correct answer is C. Structural call protection is achieved through sequential-pay tranches in the CMBS as a lower-rated tranche cannot be paid down until the higher-rated tranche is completely retired. A is incorrect because defeasance provides call protection at the individual loan level. Defeasance allows prepayment, but the borrower must purchase a portfolio of government securities that fully replicates the cash flows of the remaining scheduled principal and interest payments, including the balloon loan balance, on the loan. B is incorrect because prepayment lockout provides call protection at the individual loan level. Prepayment lockout is a contractual agreement that prohibits any prepayments during a specified period.
